post_text: We are saddened by the sudden loss of our dear friend and co-worker, Loretta Curtis-LeMay (HHS Assistant Principal). Mrs. Curtis-LeMay made a huge impact at Hopewell High School by making her sweet presence known and felt by everyone with whom she came in contact. Mrs. Curtis-LeMay was able to build positive relationships with students and parents where her heart and love was shown by her attitude and commitment to the school. We send our deepest condolences to her family, husband and daughter as they mourn the loss of their loved one. Her smiles, jokes and warm comments will be truly missed and never forgotten by the staff here at HHS. One student recently shared that Mrs. Curtis-LeMay always checked on her and made her feel special. She was a true testament to the meaning of Blue Devil Pride!

Melody Hackney, Ed.D.

post_text: Patrick Copeland 1st graders have been working on a Kindness PBL. Students have been learning about empathy and kindness towards others at school and in the community. After a visit from their Homeless Shelter expert, Pastor Michael Moore, the 1st graders became very interested in how they could help the homeless in the community. Students took on different jobs for this project. Some made the sandwiches, others packaged the them or packed the bags. The lunches included bologna sandwiches, chips, oranges, fruit bars and a water. They also made encouraging notes to include in the lunches. The 1st graders then went to the Appomattox Library to serve the lunches to the homeless. This was a very powerful lesson on empathy for our children that they will never forget. #hopewellmagic

shared_text:
Hopewell High School JROTC added 30 new photos.
February 5 at 5:01 PM ·

Today was a special day for Hopewell High School's JROTC program. Today, we pinned our own Unit Crests on Cadets! Distinctive Unit Insignia, more commonly known as Unit Crests, can be dated as far back as 1902. Unit Crests show the official coat of arms authorized for units in the United States Army. Unit Crests are designed by the Army's Department of Heraldry and reflect the heritage of each unit. Special thanks to The Kiwanis Club of Hopewell for their donation to support our acquisition of these Unit Crests! Very few JROTC programs have their own Unit Crests and we would not have been able to do this without our community's support.
Blue and yellow are our school colors. Blue symbolizes loyalty; yellow suggests excellence. The blue bend alludes to Hopewell’s location along the James River. The bendlets that parallel each other signify teamwork and honor. The torch represents knowledge; the open book symbolizes intelligence and education. The tall ship historically denotes the Hopewell, which the city and school were named after.

Catching up on old news...
Today was a surprise! The front office secretary called LTC Pape while he and the Cadets were doing PT in the Aux Gym...she said "there are four guys here in uniform to see you!" (Imagine what might have gone through LTC Pape's mind, since he had no idea anyone was coming). Four young Marines, back on their equivalent of the Army's "Hometown Recruiter" program - where they come home for the holidays but don't have to use leave, working with their recruiter part of the time. These young men did a terrific job, representing the USMC! Talked a lot of smack, of course! But they really connected with the students and made it clear - what sets the Marines apart from others.
